awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns the deep connections between two apparently very different areas of algebra. The first is group theory, which is the formal study of symmetry.  The second is algebraic number theory, the study of numbers which can be constructed by algebraic processes, like taking square roots (as opposed to numbers like e and pi which arise only through limit processes belonging to calculus). The main link between these two fields is provided by algebraic geometry, the geometric study of systems of polynomial equations.  A key theme in the proposed work is monodromy, which encapsulates the symmetries revealed by a varying system as the variable follows a closed loop.  Monodromy problems arise in many guises, in both pure and applied mathematics.  For instance some of the techniques under study in this project have been used to determine which kinds of computations can be carried out by different kinds of quantum computer.  Algebraic number theory has found important practical applications and especially plays a key role in the development of modern cryptosystems.

The theme of this project is the reciprocal relationship between group theory and algebraic number theory or arithmetic algebraic geometry.  This includes using group theory as a tool, for instance in analyzing images of l-adic Galois representations, or Mordell-Weil groups of abelian varieties over Galois extensions of the rationals.  It also includes studying groups, especially discrete linear groups (including finite groups), using methods from number theory and algebraic geometry, including the circle method, etale cohomology, and deformation theory.

por.por_cntn:
The mathematical notion of "group" is a formalization of the concept of symmetry.  Groups can be be finite (like the symmetries of a starfish) or infinite and discrete (like the symmetries of wallpaper patterns), or infinite and continuous, likes the symmetries of a cylinder or a sphere.  They can also describe symmetries in non-geometric settings, such as symmetries of fields (number systems) or the symmetries among possible states of a physical system, such as a quantum computer.

This project concerns groups both in the abstract, in the context of geometry (especially algebraic geometry, which concerns figures defined by polynomial equations), and number theory.  Results of the project include both applications of group theory to number theory and applications of algebraic geometry and number theory to group theory.

For the first, one can instance the general philosophy that could paraphrased by the slogan "symmetry groups of naturally occurring fields are usually as large as possible."  This slogan covers a range of ideas from the classical (such as classification of regular polygons which can be constructed by compass and straightedge), to major problems for the future like the Tate conjecture on algebraic cycles.

In this project, Chun Yin Hui and I considered Galois groups associated to "flat" geometric objects: abelian varieties and hyperkaehler varieties and showed that these are essentially "as large as possible", the optimal result one could hope for in this setting.

For the second, a key background fact is the "classification of finite simple groups", which classifies the basic building blocks of finite group theory. It turns out that finite simple groups can mostly be thought of as groups of square matrices whose entries are solutions to systems of algebraic equations over finite fields.  This gives an opening for ideas from algebraic geometry and especially the sophisticated methods which have been developed for counting solutions of systems of equations over finite fields.

In terms of this project, I would mention results, with various collaborators, including Robert Guralnick, Aner Shalev, and Pham Tiep, in which we count in various ways the number of solutions of equations whose variables are elements ranging over finite groups.  I would also mention recent results with Guralnick and Emmanuel Breuillard on realizing interesting groups which are infinite but discrete inside Lie groups (infinite continuous groups).

These problems have also informed my work with Ph.D. students.  At the time of my proposal, I had supervised 11 graduate students up through completion of their Ph.D.s.  Since that time, I have supervised 6 more theses through to completion, and I have several current Ph.D. students at different stages in their thesis projects.
